The  Lanzhou  Sustainable  Urban  Transport  Project  (the  Project)

in  the  PRC  and  includes  support  for  an  application  to  use  the 
Clean  Development  Mechanism  of  the  Kyoto  Protocol.  It  consists 
of  four  components  under  ADB  financing:  (i)  constructing  and 
reconstructing  33.8  kilometers  (km)  urban  roads,  including  bus 
rapid  transit  BRT  facilities  and  non-motorized  transport  (NMT) 
lanes; 
traffic  management; 
(iii)  implementing an advanced environmental monitoring system; 
and  (iv)  building  capacity  to  support  project  implementation  and 
BRT operation and management.  
 
Lanzhou,  the  capital  of  Gansu  Province,  is  a  regional  hub 
between  the  eastern  and  western  regions  of  the  PRC.  Home  to 
3.1  million  inhabitants,  it  is  the  economic,  political,  and  cultural 
center  of  Gansu.  The  city  has  four  distinct  development  zones, 
three  of  which  are  on  the  south  bank  of  the  Yellow  River,  where 
the  business,  commerce,  and  government  centers  are  located. 
The  fourth  zone  is  on  the  north  bank  of  the  river  at  Anning.  The 
Lanzhou  municipal  government (LMG)  has  adopted  a  strategy  of 
"one  river,  two  centers,  seven  groups"  as  a  key  concept  of  its 
urban  master  plan  to  optimize  land  use  and  the  economic  and 
social functions of the city. It has decided to develop a second city 
center  in  Anning.  As  Anning  will  become  the  new  political, 
administrative, economic, and cultural center of the city, there will 
be  a  significant  increase  in  demand  for  transport  to,  from,  and 
within  Anning.  The  Project  will  contribute  to  realizing  the  urban 
master  plan  by  supporting  the  development  of  the  urban  road 
network and the urban mass transport system serving the new city 
center.  It  will  focus  on  providing  a  sustainable  urban  transport 
system in Lanzhou.

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Lanzhou Sustainable Urban Transport Project 
(the  Project).  This  will  be  the  first  support  for  bus  rapid  transit  (BRT)  in  the  PRC  of  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB).  BRT  is  an  efficient  public  transport  system  that  will  provide  major 
benefits  for  passengers  and  bus  operators  and  will  reduce  fuel  consumption  and  greenhouse 
gas  (GHG)  emissions.  The  Project  is  part  of  ADB's  initiative  to  support  greener,  more 
sustainable  transport  in  the  PRC  and  includes  support  for  an  application  to  use  the  Clean 
Development  Mechanism  (CDM)  of  the  Kyoto  Protocol.  The  main  features  of  the  proposed 
Project are summarized in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

The  PRC  has  experienced  significant  economic  progress.  Rapid  industrialization  and 
2. 
urbanization have seen the PRC economy grow very quickly, averaging more than 9% annually 
since 1978 and over 10% annually from 2001 to 2008. Gross domestic product (GDP) in 2008 
was  CNY30.07  trillion  ($4.40  trillion),  83  times  the  GDP  of  CNY362.4  billion  ($53.08  billion) 
3  decades earlier in 1978. Per capita GDP in 2008 was CNY22,698 ($3,324).  
 
3. 
The  development  of  transport  infrastructure,  including  expressways  and  other  road 
networks,  has  played  a  significant  role  in  enabling  sustained  economic  growth,  which  has 
substantially increased demand for transport. By the end of 2008, the PRC had a road network 
of  3.73  million  kilometers  (km),  including  60,300  km  of  expressways,  54,200  km  of  class  I 
highways, 285,200 km of class II highways, 2.38 million km of class III and class IV highways, 
and 951,600 km of rural and other roads. By 2008, road transport accounted for 54.1% of total 
passenger-km travelled and 12.3% of freight traffic in ton-km, compared with 33.3% and 23.8% 
for rail and 0.3% and 61.8% for waterways. 
 
4. 
With  increases  in  per  capita  incomes,  as  well  as  reduced  customs  duties  on  vehicles 
following  PRC  accession  to  the  World  Trade  Organization,  the  number  of  registered  vehicles 
increased from about 1 million in the early 1990s to 43.58 million in 2008. Over the past 5 years, 
the  number  of  registered  vehicles  has  increased  at  an  average  annual  rate  of  16.3%.  Vehicle 
ownership reached 33 vehicles per 1,000 people nationwide in 2008. It is expected to continue 
to  increase  rapidly,  considering  that  vehicle  ownership  per  1,000  people  is  generally  in  the 
range of 300–800 in industrialized countries. Vehicles bring enormous benefits to the economy 
and users by enhancing mobility. Rapidly growing demand, especially for private vehicles, is a 
manifestation of the mobility benefits. However, associated with these benefits are the emerging 
problems  of  traffic  congestion,  road  accidents,  air  pollution,  and  greenhouse  gas  (GHG) 
emissions that cause widespread concern. 
 
5. 
Urban areas in the PRC have grown rapidly since the 1980s and now contribute 80% of 
GDP.  To  increase  personal  income  and  achieve  a  better  quality  of  life,  many  people  have 
moved  from  the  countryside  to  the  cities.  Some  300–400  million  people  migrated  in  a  single 
generation. The PRC’s urban population accounted for 44.9% of the national population in 2007 
and  is  expected  to  reach  47.0%  by  2010.  Rapid  economic  growth  and  rural–urban  migration 
have  changed the  structure  of urban transport. Suburban  areas  have  developed  around many 
cities for new residents. This has made it more difficult for people to rely on biking and walking 
and thereby increased the need for public transport. As vehicle ownership trends indicate, there

has been a continuing shift toward using private vehicles for urban transport, but this trend is not 
sustainable because of the congestion it causes and the resulting deterioration in the quality of 
service and efficiency of both private and public transport.  
 
Rapid motorization has allowed municipal governments little time to prepare strategically 
6. 
effective  responses  or  build  institutional  capacity  for  urban  transport.  They  have  responded  to 
demand for more road space by investing heavily in road capacity and, in most cities, adopted 
piece-meal and stop-gap measures. The main solution to complex urban transport problems lies 
in  developing  efficient  and  affordable  public  transport  systems,  together  with  effective  pricing 
and  other  policies  to  manage  demand  for  private  vehicles.  It  is  becoming  clearer  to  the 
Government of the PRC (the Government) that increasing the capacity and efficiency of public 
transport would contribute greatly to sustainable development. 
 
7. 
The PRC has become the world’s second-largest oil consumer, having gone from being 
a net exporter of crude oil to importing a third of its fuel. The PRC contributed more than 40% of 
the  increase  in  global  demand  for  primary  energy  between  2000  and  2006.  Despite  low 
emissions per capita, it became the world’s largest national GHG emitter in 2006, and its GHG 
emissions are increasing rapidly as the economy continues to grow. Its total GHG emissions are 
projected to rise by 65–80% over the 15 years from 2006 to 2020.  
 
8. 
Road transport is a significant and increasingly important contributor to PRC emissions 
of GHG. The transport sector currently accounts for 8% of energy consumption in the PRC, but 
this  is  projected  to  increase  to  15%  by  2030.  Petroleum  consumption  was  10  million  tons  in 
2005,  with  vehicles  accounting  for  30%.  By  2020,  when  the  number  of  registered  vehicles  is 
projected  to  reach  170  million,  petroleum  consumption  is  projected  to  reach  100  million  tons, 
with vehicles accounting for 57%. Road GHG emissions are expected to increase by the same 
proportion. Burning 100 million tons of petroleum will emit 320 million tons of GHG.

Lanzhou,  the  capital  of  Gansu  Province,  is  a  regional  hub  between  the  eastern  and 
western  regions  of  the  PRC.  Home  to  3.1  million  inhabitants,  it  is  the  economic,  political,  and 
cultural center of Gansu. The population density of Lanzhou is 252 people per square kilometer 
(km2),  more  than  4  times  that  of  Gansu.  The  main  city  is  located  on  the  banks  of  the  Yellow 
River  and  contained  within  a  narrow  east–west  valley  with  steep  terrain  at  both  the  north  and 
south  that  effectively  constrains  further  expansion  of  the  city.  The  urban  area  stretches  for 
almost 40 km along the river from west to east but extends only 8 km from north to south and, at 
its narrowest point, is less than 1 km wide.  
 
The city has four distinct development zones. Three—Xigu, Qilihe, and Chengguan—are

business,  commerce,  and  government.  The  fourth  zone  is  on  the  north  bank  of  the  river  at

Anning,  a  residential  area  that  is  also  a  center  for  education,  including  universities.  Economic 
activity  and  population  are  heavily  concentrated  in  the  four  urban  districts,  which  occupy  only 
8.5%  of  Lanzhou’s  land  area  but  account  for  62.9%  of  its  population  and  80.2%  of  its  gross 
regional product. There is limited potential for further growth of the city along the south bank. In 
Chengguan,  in  particular,  population  density  has  reached  18,000/km2,  bringing  considerable 
congestion and pollution. There is good potential for developing the city in Anning, where 80% 
of the land is suitable for settlement and the population density of only 3,400/km2. 
 
Future urban development will therefore require a second city center to be developed at 
12. 
Anning.  To  realize  this  opportunity,  the  Lanzhou  municipal  government  (LMG)  has  adopted  a 
strategy of "one river, two centers, seven groups" as the key concept of its urban master plan to 
optimize land use and the economic and social functions of the city. In support of this plan, the

4. 

Lesson Learned  

 
27. 
In  addition  to  supply-side  measures  such  as  the  provision  of  road  infrastructure, 
demand-side  policy  measures  to  limit  the  use  of  private  vehicles  are  required  to  avoid  traffic 
congestion  problems.  Many  large  cities  have  shown  that  supply-side  expansion  can  quickly 
cause severe traffic congestion when not accompanied by sufficient measures to make the use 
of  private  vehicles  relatively  less  attractive.  In  addition  to  restricting  private  vehicle  use, 
demand-side  measures  such  as  traffic  demand  management  (TDM)  have  good  potential  to 
create an additional revenue stream to help finance public transport improvements. One of the 
simplest approaches is to charge a relatively high fee for parking in city centers, thereby making 
car  use  less  attractive  than  public  transport.  Singapore  and  London  are  among  the  cities  that 
have  demonstrated  various  other  regulatory  and  demand-side  measures  to  limit  vehicle 
numbers and reduce demand for vehicle use in congested city centers.

investment  with  proactive  interventions  to  improve  public  transport  and  introduce  TDM.  The 
combined  transport  strategy  and  policy  may  include  BRT  or  priority  public  transport  schemes, 
restraints on car traffic in congested areas or at certain times of day, and congestion pricing for 
road use.

63. 
The  traffic  forecast  was  prepared  by  Lanzhou  Jiaotong  University  using  a  conventional 
four-stage  transport  model  with  a  12x12  zone  origin–destination  trip  matrix.  The  university 
conducted the origin–destination survey in 2001 to support the comprehensive Lanzhou Transport 
Plan. Transport planning software called TRANSCARD was used in the traffic demand analysis 
to  simulate  traffic  flows  in  the  base  year,  2008,  and  for  projections  for  2013,  2015,  2020,  and 
2025. Updated traffic data for the base year was obtained from traffic counts conducted in 2008. 
Traffic accident statistics and bus operation surveys were used in the analysis.  
 
64. 
The  economic  analysis  compared  the  “without  project”  and  “with  project”  scenarios.  The 
costs  included  capital  costs  for  physical  networks  and  BRT  works,  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement, environmental control and monitoring, detailed engineering design, implementation 
supervision,  and  physical  contingencies.  Annualized  recurring  costs  for  road  maintenance, 
environmental  monitoring,  and  the  opportunity  cost  of  land  were  included  in  the  analysis.  The 
quantified network benefits included time savings for passengers and freight, vehicle operating 
costs, and reduced traffic accidents and vehicle emissions. The economic internal rate of return 
under  the  most  likely  traffic  growth  scenario  is  17.02%  with  a  net  present  value  of  CNY1.65 
billion  using  a  discount  rate  of  12%.  Sensitivity  tests  were  performed  to  examine  the  effect  of 
alternative traffic growth  rates,  likely  cost  overruns,  likely  benefit  reductions,  and  combinations 
of contingencies. The test results indicate that project economic viability is robust. Moreover, the 
review of benefit distribution among different income groups shows that public transport users, 
pedestrians, and bicyclists will be the prime beneficiaries of the Project (Appendix 13).

4. 
Public Transport. Public transport in Lanzhou is undertaken in taxis and buses. Trolley 
buses were discontinued in 2008, and the rail lines crossing the city are used mainly by intercity

vehicles  progressively  dominated  the  roads  and  as  trip  distances  grew  in  line  with  the  city's 
expansion. There are worsening safety problems because pedestrian crossings are few and are 
frequently obstructed; NMT lanes have been encroached on by motor vehicles, either moving or 
parked;  and  cyclists  are  often  forced  to  operate  in  dangerous  mixed  traffic.  Lack  of  parking 
facilities and risk of theft are cited as significant impediments for bicycle use.  
 
9. 
NMT,  as  a  mode  chosen  by  the  users  rather  than  imposed  by  poverty,  will  be  an 
essential element of the city's transport system. An integrated network of protected or separated 
bicycle  lanes  is  needed,  together  with  bicycle  parking  facilities  at  bus  stations.  Bicycle  rental

appropriate sidewalks, mid-block crossings, and pedestrian signals. Efforts are needed to create 
a  more  attractive  streetscape,  as  well  as  to  make  urban  blocks  either  smaller  or  allow  NMT 
through traffic.

Transport  Externalities.  The  increased  use  of  motor  vehicles  has  heightened  road 
safety  concerns  in  Lanzhou.  The  incidence  and  severity  of  accidents  are  relatively  high  when 
compared with other cities of similar population. Lanzhou had 723 traffic accidents in 2007 that 
caused 723 injuries and 305 fatalities, 57% of which were pedestrians (Table A3.3). The fatality

Bus Rapid Transit Corridor 

 
1. 
Urbanization has rapidly increased demand for urban transport in Anning and throughout 
Lanzhou. The population of Anning in 2007 was 234,400, of which 88% was classified as urban.

the number of registered passenger vehicles is expected to grow by 6.8 times, and the number 
of  buses  is  expected  to  grow  by  1.9  times.  Bus  rapid  transit  (BRT)  can  sustainably  meet 
demand  for  urban  transport  in  Lanzhou  and  mitigate  negative  externalities.  It  offers  low-cost, 
efficient, flexible, and environmentally friendly mass transport. BRT will be constructed mainly in 
the Anning new city center, but the BRT corridor will across the Yellow River and connect to the 
current city center. This connection will increase the efficiency and convenience of BRT as part 
of  Lanzhou's  urban  mass  transport  system  and  strengthen  the  outcome  and  impact  of  the 
Lanzhou Sustainable Urban Transport Project (the Project).

5.

BRT  need to  be  designed  taking  into  account the  experiences  of  existing  BRT  systems  in the 
PRC  and  elsewhere.  The  proposed  22  stations  in  the  Lanzhou  BRT  will  provide  average 
spacing of around 600 meters between stations, taking into account the current locations of the 
bus stations, Lanzhou Urban Master Plan, Lanzhou New City Area Plan, and findings of demand 
surveys, including of the number of passengers at peak hours in the morning and evening. One 
of  the  lessons  from  other  BRTs  in  the  PRC  is  that  BRT  stations  should  not  be  located  near 
intersections,  as  this  often  results  in  vehicles  blocking  the  intersections  and  pedestrian 
crossings. All stations of the Lanzhou BRT are located at least 75 meters from intersections but 
close  to  existing  bus  stops.  Another  lesson  is  that  some  BRT  systems  fail  to  realize  potential 
time  saving  benefits  for  bus  passengers  and  road  users  if  there  are  long  queues  at  ticket

Traffic Demand Management 

 
1. 
There  is  a  growing  understanding  among  policy-makers  that  relying  on  infrastructure 
construction alone  that does  not  sustainably  solve  urban traffic  congestion. It  is  inefficient  and 
costly in the long term. Regulatory and demand-side policies offer complementary instruments 
to meet the needs of users. Traffic demand management (TDM) is the process of adjusting or 
adapting  the  use  of  an  existing  road  system  to  meet  specified  objectives  without  resorting  to 
substantial  new  road  construction.  Effective  traffic  management  can  increase  the  capacity  of 
existing  transport  infrastructure  by  managing  traffic  flows  and  helping  to  address  traffic 
congestion,  road  accidents,  and  vehicle  emissions. The  proposed  Lanzhou  Sustainable  Urban 
Transport Project (the Project) will support (i) establishing a TDM strategy and reforming policy 
on  traffic  management  in  Lanzhou,  (ii)  developing  an  advanced  traffic  control  system  (signal 
control), and (iii) preparing a development plan for non-motorized transport (NMT). 
 
A. 
 
2. 
TDM  strategies  address  traffic  congestion  by  reducing  or  optimizing  demand  for 
transport and influencing user behavior. TDM attempts to influence travelers before they get into 
their  cars  by  promoting  alternative  modes  and  destinations  of  travel  and  providing  improved 
options  for  drivers.  A  first  set  of  measures  aims  to  make  efficient  transport  options—such  as 
park-and-ride,  work  schedule  adjustments, 
flexi-time  and/or  compressed  workweek, 
telecommuting,  and  car  pooling—more  attractive  to  users,  as  well  as  facilitate  NMT  with  safe, 
integrated  walking  and  biking  paths  and  bicycle  parking.  A  second  set  is  market-based 
measures to reorient user behavior through price incentives. This may include road tolls that are 
either  fixed  or  vary  with  congestion,  area  or  cordon  pricing  for  urban  centers,  pricing  parking 
spaces, subsidizing transit fares, pay-as-you-drive vehicle insurance schemes, and increases to 
fuel or vehicle taxes. A third set of measures limits traffic to certain types of vehicles in certain 
areas or corridors, road rationing through alternative driving schemes (such as in Sao Paulo), or 
vehicle purchase auctions such as in Singapore or Shanghai.

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  

 
The Lanzhou Sustainable Urban Transport Project (the Project) includes urban road infrastructure that will support new

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                         Targeting Classification: General intervention 
1. Key Issues. Only 5%–10% of the population of Anning is poor because it is located in the urban area of Lanzhou. 
The main causes of poverty are unemployment and families with members who are disabled or have serious illnesses. 
The Lanzhou municipal government (LMG) has social security policies to support these households. 
 
Anning  is  going  through  a  period  of  rapid  economic  growth  and  social  development.  It  was  already  the  cultural  and 
educational center of Lanzhou and, in 2004, was designated the new central business district and locus for LMG.  
 
Anning  has  a  number  of  poverty  safeguards  established,  such  as  the  minimum  living  security  system,  medical 
insurance system for minimum living security recipients, low-rent housing system for minimum income recipients, and 
urban-rural endowment insurance system. 

The Project will benefit the poor but is not classified as a poverty intervention because the poor and others alike will 
have access to and benefit from the various road and transport service developments.   
 
2.  Design  Features.  The project design has stressed inclusive benefits for all people using the transport network in 
Anning.  Equal  attention has  been  given  to  vehicles,  non-motorized  vehicles,  and  pedestrians.  People in  Anning  rely 
heavily on bus transport, and the Project aims to strengthen bus mass transit in an affordable manner for all citizens. 
LMG provides lower fares for vulnerable groups and the elderly. Traffic management and road safety are features to 
address  congestion  and  mixed  traffic  flows.  Special  consideration  has  been  provided  for  the  disabled.  These 
measures  and  design  features  are  set  out  in  the  Social  Development  Action  and  Monitoring  Plan  (SDAMP).  The 
resettlement plan includes exchange housing that ensures good-quality housing for low-income households.

integrated  circuit  card  readers,  and  other  equipment  on  the  bus.  The  company  recruits  100 
passengers  annually,  paying  each  CNY480  per  year  to  report  on  15  routes  per  month  with 
numerical grades for each question, thereby evaluating 18,000 trips per year.  

Operating Statistics and Productivity 

3. 
 
7. 
During  the  5-year  period  from  2004  to  2008,  the  total  route  length  increased  by  0.6% 
annually, from 1,056 km to 1,076 km. The number of LPTG bus routes meanwhile fell from 100 
to 92 (by 2.1% per year). When the average annual increase of 11.7% in ridership is considered 
for  the  same  period,  it  is  evident  that  the  reduction  in  the  number  of  routes  has  consolidated 
service  with  higher  efficiency  in  equipment  and  employee  productivity.  For  example,  average 
annual  revenue  per  bus  increased  from  CNY132,650  in  2004  to  CNY210,950  in  2008,  for  a 
12.3% increase annually; average revenue per passenger increased from CNY0.76 to CNY0.81, 
or 1.6% annually; and average annual passenger trips per employee increased from 48,030 to 
70,710 in 2008, increasing by 10.2% per year.  

8. 
It  is  projected  that,  during  the  10  years  from  2009  to  2018,  the  total  route  length  will 
increase  by  0.8%  annually,  from  1,089  km  in  2009  to  1,168  km  in  2018.  The  number  of  bus 
routes  is  expected to  increase from  92  to  96  as  new  routes  will  be  added for the  planned  the 
new  city  center,  new  residential  and  commercial  areas,  and  BRT.  Employee  productivity  is 
expected  to  gradually  increase  from  3.66  staffers  per  bus  in  2009  to  3.34  staffers  per  bus  in 
2018, and the average number of passenger trips per employee from 74,950 in 2009 to 119,630 
in 2018. The number of buses in operation is expected to increase from 2,089 in 2009 to 4,495 
in 2018, while the revenue per passenger is forecast to increase at the same rate of 1.6% per 
annum as in the 2004–2008 period.  

9. 
In general, LPTC bus operations indicate an efficiently run operation with relatively high 
employee  productivity,  though  with  some  room  for  improvement.  With  increasing  demand  for 
public passenger transport, additional buses will be needed since fleet utilization is now running 
at  261,630  passengers  per  bus  annually.  Even  with  doubling  the  fleet  size,  productivity  is 
expected to increase by 52.8% to 399,830 passengers per bus by 2018. 

Financial Assessment 

B. 
 
10. 
The  audited  financial  statements  of  LPTG  for  2004–2008  have  been  analyzed.  They 
include the income statement and cash flow statement for the year and the balance sheet as of 
the end of the year. The company’s fiscal year coincides with the calendar year.  

11. 
The  LPTG  bus  division  shows  a  consistently  positive  net  operating  profit,  ranging  from 
CNY56.75  million  in  2004  (22.3%  of  revenue)  to  CNY63.26  million  in  2008  (15%  of  revenue) 
with the operating ratio (operating expenses divided by operating revenue) ranging from 73.0% 
in 2006 to 85.0% in 2008. The working capital ratio (which deducts depreciation from operating

expenses) ranged from 64.3% in 2006 to 78.1% in 2008, and this also shows strong operating 
performance by the bus division.  

12.  When administrative overhead and other non-operating expenses are included, the bus 
division’s profitability shows mixed results, with 2004, 2005, and 2008 showing a net loss before 
tax  and  2006  and  2007  showing  a  modest  profit.  Despite  its  emphasis  on  public  service, 
however, during the 5 years from 2004 to 2008, the cumulative losses for the bus division are 
more than offset by the cumulative profits, for a total accumulated profit before tax of CNY25.61 
million, or an average of CNY5.12 million per year. 

13. 
The financial condition of LPTG would be improved if losses from non-bus divisions were 
eliminated through divestiture or if the accounting and financial records of the bus division were 
separated from the other divisions. The hotel division in particular fails to show a profit, and its 
inclusion as a division of LPTG, which is primarily a bus transport company, is a burden on the 
profitability of its primary operations.  

LPTG’s historical current ratio ranged from 0.64 in 2005 to 1.34 in 2008. These ratios are 
14. 
low  and  reflect  liquidity  problems  in  some  years,  particularly  when  the  quick  ratio  has  fallen 
below 1.0, which happened in 4 of the past 5 years. The debt-to-equity ratio during the past 5 
years  averaged  1.05,  showing  rough  parity  between  equity  and  liabilities.  Although  this  ratio 
could  be  a  concern  in  relation  to  the  ability  of  LPTG  to  borrow  further  on  the  strength  of  its 
balance sheet, about 65% of the company’s debt is to its parent, LMG, in the form of long-term 
liability  resulting  from  accounting  adjustments  arising  with  ownership  reform  initiated  prior  to 
2004. This long-term debt could be written off to improve the debt-to-equity ratio substantially. 

15. 
During  the  next  4  years,  from  2009  to  2012,  LPTG  operations  are  expected  to  bring 
cumulative  losses  before  tax  of  CNY52.0  million,  or  an  average  of  CNY13.0  million  annually. 
These  expected  losses  do  not  result  from  the  bus  division,  which  is  expected  to  realize  a 
cumulative  net  profit  before  tax  of  CNY92.0  million  during  the  same  period,  or  an  average  of 
CNY23.0 million year. With the commencement of BRT services in 2013, the bus division’s profit 
before  tax  is  projected  to  increase.  After  2013,  largely  because  of  BRT  operations,  the  bus 
division’s profit before tax is expected to offset the losses of the other divisions.
